talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes clause 41. Amendment No. 2 seeks the deletion of section 44 from the proposed Federal Magistrates Bill 1999 . That section will allow the minister to specify the mandatory transfer of specified proceedings from the Federal Magistrates Court to the Family and Federal courts. We surmise that that is in the event that it is ascertained, for instance, that the Federal Magistrates Court is being flooded by a particular sort of matter—for example, excessive bankruptcy matters—which preclude its disposal of other matters. The bill as drafted proposes to give the Attorney-General power by regulation to transfer all those bankruptcy matters—as the case may be—back into the Federal Court. While there may be a rational basis for taking such action, we strongly oppose the Attorney—not the Attorney but more the office of the Attorney—having that power to so transfer matters between any jurisdiction. We think the jurisdiction of any court or significant tribunal should be set by the parliament rather than by any individual minister—in this case, the Attorney-General.

speech.para: The amendment also relates, I should say, to consequent amendments that we will be moving to the consequential amendments bill, but I will talk about those when we get to them. Essentially, however, the principle upon which we are opposing section 41 is, as I have said, that it will enable the Attorney-General rather than the parliament to determine the jurisdiction of the courts. I should indicate that if and when the government may desire to extend or limit the jurisdiction of the Magistrates Court, the Federal Court or the Family Court, we will be prepared to look at that issue on its merits. However, we are not going to give the government power in advance to determine any of those very significant issues. We note that such a regulation would be a disallowable instrument but, nonetheless, we consider as a matter of principle—supported by the Law Council, I should add, on this matter—that it should be parliament rather than any individual minister or the Attorney-General which determines the jurisdiction of any court.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes clause 41 by this amendment. The clause allows regulations to be made which mandate the transfer of proceedings from the Federal Magistrates Service to either the Federal Court or the Family Court. I respect the spirit in which the amendment is moved. In principle, there is some merit in what the member for Barton says. I note also that the Senate committee reports—in the minority report—that opposition on this point is on the grounds that the jurisdictions of courts should be determined by statute, not by the government of the day.

speech.para: As I said, clause 41 would allow regulations to be made which would mandate the transfer of proceedings from the Federal Magistrates Service to either the Federal Court or the Family Court. This clause would give flexibility in managing the workload of the courts to ensure that the workload is appropriately balanced between the courts. Given the high volume and the potential for high levels of change in the nature of proceedings before both courts, this is a tool, I think, that is both appropriate and necessary. The member for Barton notes that the regulations would be disallowable. It might be added on that basis that parliament would still therefore retain control over whether any changes were made. I note that the regulations will not come into effect until the period for disallowance by parliament has expired.

In the light of experience, after some time—and it may be a considerable time—it may be possible to do what the member for Barton suggests without risking the imbalance of the workload of the courts but, at this stage, projection of that would not be feasible.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 9:

speech.para: (9) Clause 44, page 27 (lines 16 and 17), omit paragraph (b).

Amendment No. 9 is a simple amendment. It proposes the deletion of clause 44 paragraph (b) of the bill. The proposed section is designed to permit the Attorney-General to determine by regulation that a person other than a barrister or solicitor or otherwise authorised by any other law of the Commonwealth can represent a person in proceedings before the court. Again, it is the view of the Australian Labor Party that that should be determined by legislation and not by regulation. In particular, there is a risk of bestowing the right of representation upon a sectional interest group or lobby group that has a particular axe to grind or principle to pursue, and there is a risk, if members of such an organisation were given a right of appearance, that they would pursue the grievances or the interests of that particular organisation rather than those of the litigant before the court. That potential is of concern to the Labor Party. It may well be that classes of persons—trade unions in the industrial field, for instance—are frequently given the right of representation by statute in breach of award cases and the like but, again, we say it is appropriate for any such initiative to face the review of the parliament rather than the review of any individual minister or Attorney-General. On that basis we have moved our amendment.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes this amendment. It would delete paragraph 44(b) from the bill. This paragraph allows regulations to be made entitling persons to represent litigants in proceedings in the Federal Magistrates Service. From the Senate committee minority report, it appears that the opposition objects to this paragraph on the basis that any rights of representation should be set out in the bill rather than be determined by regulation. That is really exactly what the member for Barton says.

speech.para: Paragraph 44(b) provides flexibility in determining who could represent parties in proceedings in the Federal Magistrates Service. It is too early at this stage, when the court has not even been established, to include in the bill the categories of people whom it may be appropriate to authorise as representatives. It should be borne in mind that it is contemplated that the court will have a wide jurisdiction ranging from matters as diverse as workplace relations on the one hand, to human rights and matters arising in the trade and commerce area. In the family area, there would equally be quite a range from, potentially, abduction cases which may or may not be international to the ordinary contact and residence cases relating to children.

The workload of the court will need to be examined once it is in operation, to look at whether there exists any need for representation which could be met by allowing appropriate categories of persons to represent litigants. Of course, regulations would not be made without looking carefully at the ability of the particular categories of persons to adequately represent litigants and to act responsibly and professionally. The government would want to make sure that representatives would be of assistance to their clients and the court, rather than a hindrance.

The member for Barton seems to infer that there might be favouritism towards people of a particular class being given power to represent litigants, as against other classes. It is contemplated that the regulations would in fact assist litigants with limited resources, who may not be able to afford to pay for legal representation. Again, any regulations would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny by being disallowable.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes clauses 45 and 46. These amendments propose the deletion of sections 45 and 46 of the bill. Section 45 deals with permission to administer interrogatories and discovery, and section 46 deals with permission to issue subpoenas in proceedings before the Federal Magistrates Court. Section 45(i) provides that interrogatories and discovery are not allowed in relation to proceedings in the Federal Magistrates Court unless the court or a magistrate declares that it is appropriate, in the interests of the administration of justice, to allow the interrogatories or discovery. We say that that clearly casts the onus on the person seeking the leave to administer those interrogatories or discovery to obtain it, and that is inappropriate.

speech.para: Similarly, as a matter of the same principle, in respect to subpoenas, for instance, subsection 46(4) provides that the Federal Magistrates Court or a federal magistrate must not grant leave to issue a subpoena under subsection 3 unless the party seeking the subpoena satisfies the Federal Magistrates Court or the federal magistrate that it is in the interests of justice to issue the subpoena. So in fact it is probably, on that different wording, an even stricter test than that provided for in section 45. But we say that that is inappropriate. While there can be many instances where parties can use these procedures to go on fishing expeditions or to unreasonably bog down the process of litigation, equally, particularly in the Family Court—although I have to say also that this occurs equally in the trade practices area—these can be essential to the conduct of litigation.

In respect of family law, for instance, it is often extremely difficult, if one of the parties is involved in a business, for the other party to be aware of the actual income or the totality of assets of that party. It is often the case that meaningful settlement negotiations and mediation cannot occur until all the facts are on the table. So the ability to get that information, if it is being unreasonably withheld, is very important. Quite often, experience suggests that when the information is on the table the parties are more realistic in their approach to appropriate resolution of the matters in dispute. So we say it is counterproductive to impose that rigid test, as provided for in sections 45 and 46. Accordingly, our amendments seek the deletion of those sections.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes amendment No. 10, which seeks to remove clause 45 from the bill. As the member for Barton pointed out, the clause provides that interrogatories and discovery under the clause are not allowable unless the Federal Magistrates Service declares that it is appropriate in the interests of the administration of justice. In reaching this decision, the service must consider whether allowing such steps would be likely to contribute to the fair and expeditious conduct of the proceedings.

speech.para: It is clear that this clause does not prevent discovery and interrogatories being used. It merely provides that the leave of the Federal Magistrates Service is needed before they can be used. The ALRC has in fact found that the interlocutory proceedings, such as discovery and interrogatories, are sometimes used by lawyers as a delaying tactic or to run up legal costs. I am sure the member for Barton has had experience in his former legal practice—as I have had in mine—that interlocutory processes can be oppressive and, really, used for that purpose in litigation. This clause will assist in reducing costs to litigants and preventing litigants imposing unnecessary costs on other parties. It is also to be borne in mind that this relates to proceedings at the magistrates level.

If one takes as an example the Federal Court, it is not uncommon for the judge, in supervising a particular piece of litigation under the docket system, to actually limit discovery and interrogatories and deal with subpoenas at directions hearings in the very way that it is intended that clause 45 will operate in relation to interrogatories and discovery. It would be up to the court itself to determine how this clause would operate in practice, and no doubt it would make rules enabling appropriate decisions to be made in individual cases.

Amendment No. 11 seeks to eliminate clause 46 from the bill. This relates to subpoenas. The rationale for clause 46 is the same as that limiting discovery and interrogatories. The ALRC has also found that the use of subpoenas can sometimes result in undue cost, delay or unfairness. This clause would assist in reducing unnecessary costs incurred both by parties and more often by non-parties in complying with onerous subpoenas. This is often a real problem in the Federal and Family courts, even at this present time. Clause 46 would allow the Federal Magistrates Service to exercise better control over the use of subpoenas in the same way that clause 45 would enable them to exercise better control over interrogatories and discovery. As I said, the government opposes these amendments.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes clause 76. Amendment No. 12 relates also to amendment No. 9 of the Federal Magistrates (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 which I will be moving subsequently, but amendment No. 12 seeks the deletion of clause 76 of the bill. Subsection 76(1) will permit the Federal Magistrates Court to give reasons either orally in writing. While giving reasons orally if there are sufficient and adequate transcription services may not be such a problem, the giving of reasons under section 76(4) in short form may well be.

speech.para: We are strongly of the opinion that the giving of reasons is important because it enables the parties to assess whether the arguments and evidence that they have presented have been comprehended and considered by the court. Also, it provides for judicial accountability in terms of the competence of the magistrate in determining issues on the basis of their merits. It also, of course, provides the means of developing precedent—if reasons for decision are given they can be referred to in subsequent cases—and it enables the parties who have been unsuccessful to consider the merits of the tribunal with a view to considering whether an appeal has prospects of success. Section 76(5) indeed goes so far as to exclude the operation of section 25D of the Acts Interpretation Act, which states:

Where an Act requires a tribunal, body or person making a decision to give written reasons for the decision, whether the expression "reasons", "grounds" or any other expression is used, the instrument giving the reasons shall also set out the findings on material questions of fact and refer to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based.

Section 25D is based on the fundamental principles of natural justice that a decision maker deliberating in respect of the interests of competing parties is obliged to give reasons on that basis. In its submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, the Law Council said of this provision:

The Law Council finds it extraordinary that the government is proposing that a court constituted under chapter 3 of the Constitution would not be required to set out findings on material questions of fact nor refer to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based.
The Law Council went on to say:
Depriving litigants of the reasons for a magistrate's decision is an extremely serious course of action.

We in the Australian Labor Party do not believe that the interests of expedited justice should erode the quality of justice. Australians coming before the Federal Magistrates Court are entitled to know why decisions are being made either for or against them. Public confidence and indeed the rule of law demands no less, and accordingly we do not support these proposed sections of the bill.

talk.start.para: —Again the government opposes this amendment. Clause 76 is sought to be removed in its entirety. The reason for this is not altogether clear, either from the minority report of the Labor members of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee or from what the member for Barton has just said. The Senate committee in fact only recommended that provision for short form reasons to be deleted on the basis that parties should know why a decision is being made for or against them. Subclause 76(1) provides that the Federal Magistrates Service may give reasons either orally or in writing. As indicated in the explanatory memorandum, this clause will not alter any common law obligations which exist for courts to give reasons for decisions. Its purpose is to encourage federal magistrates to give oral reasons in appropriate cases rather than reserving their decisions. This will add to the efficient conduct of proceedings and save judicial time, leading to a better use of judicial resources.

speech.para: What is at the bottom of this is a question of culture. We do not want to see the Magistrates Court develop into the sort of court that superior courts are, where virtually all decisions are reserved and formal written reasons are delivered on the basis that the reasons may or may not effect a change in the law. The purpose of subclauses 76(2) and (3) is also to encourage federal magistrates to give oral reasons where appropriate. Subclause 76(4) allows the court to give reasons in short form in accordance with the rules of the court. This clause does not override any common law obligation like 76(1) to give proper reasons for decision. Magistrates will still give reasons but the rules of court could set out when it would be appropriate to give shorter reasons than usual and the form that these reasons must take.

It is more appropriate to allow the court to determine through its rules—and, I would add, through its practice—when short form reasons can be used without being too prescriptive about this in the bill. The clause would allow the court the flexibility to ensure that appropriate judicial resources are being devoted to a case dependent upon its complexity. It would be unlikely that magistrates would open themselves to being overturned on appeal by a failure to explain the legal reasoning behind a decision.

Clause 76(5) provides that section 25D of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 does not apply to the giving of reasons by the Federal Magistrates Service. This ensures that, if the rules of court allow the court to give short-form reasons, the rules of court, rather than the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, can prescribe what those reasons should contain. I reject the comment referred to by the member for Barton from the Law Council of Australia. By removing the obligation to comply with section 25D of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, there is no intention to prevent or deprive magistrates of the opportunity to provide statements as to the evidence, findings on the evidence and conclusions of law; that magistrates would be able to deal with the issue in any appropriate way, subject to common law obligations, subject to amendments by clause 76 and by any rules of court made relevantly.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 13 and 14:

speech.para: (13) Schedule 1, item 1, page 78 (lines 20 to 23), omit sub-clause (6).
(14) Schedule 1, item 1, page 79 (lines 1 to 6), omit paragraphs (c) and (d).

These are our final amendments in respect of the Federal Magistrates Bill 1999 . These amendments will delete clause 1(6) and paragraphs 1(7)(c) and (d) of schedule 1 to the bill. These are the personal provisions relating to federal magistrates and are specific to the appointment of federal magistrates. The relevant subclauses and paragraphs that we are seeking to delete would facilitate the appointment of part-time magistrates. We note the government's argument that it would facilitate, for instance, the appointment of a parent with child-rearing responsibilities. While we are sympathetic to that reasoning, we do not think it is being achieved in an appropriate way.

We believe that the holders of judicial office under chapter III of our Constitution should generally be appointed on a full-time basis. To do otherwise creates the potential for conflicts of interest between the persons judicial and other possibly professional duties that are not acceptable considering their judicial role. As I have said, we understand the government's reasoning in terms of assisting magistrates with parental responsibilities. However, the measure is not satisfactory in that it would apply only to those whose child-rearing responsibilities—assuming that is the motive—existed before they became magistrates. It would not apply, for instance, to those who were already magistrates and subsequently had children or their partner had children. The proposal is not sufficiently flexible to enable that to occur. The mechanism proposed by the government would not enable existing magistrates to respond to those complex demands on their time.

Further, there is no explanation from the government as to why this particular policy as it would apply to magistrates should be available to magistrates only and not to other judges. A more flexible response would need to be mindful of the requirements of section 72(iii) of the Constitution, which ensures that the remuneration of a chapter III judge may not be diminished during their continuation in office.

Essentially, the Labor Party believes that the government, if it is genuine in its desire to facilitate the appointment of those with parental responsibilities to the position of magistrate, has not provided adequate protection against potential conflicts of interest. While we do not support this provision at this point in time, we would encourage the government to consider the issue in more detail to see whether a more satisfactory solution to the problem can be found as it would apply to the judiciary generally.

talk.start.para: —The government again opposes these amendments. Amendment 13 would delete item 1(6) from schedule 1. Subitem (6) allows federal magistrates to be appointed on a part-time basis. Amendment 14 would delete paragraphs 1(7)(c) and (d) from schedule 1, which would be consequential upon amendment 13 in respect of which there would be no part-time magistrates. From the Senate committee report, it appears that the main basis for the opposition proposing this amendment is the view that inadequate protection has been included against the potential for conflicts of interest and that the complexities of the issues involved have not been sufficiently addressed, and the member for Barton has made similar suggestions in his comments.

speech.para: I would like to assure the member for Barton that the government has very carefully considered this and taken considerable advice. In fact, the issue of part-time judicial officers under chapter III of the Constitution is an issue that has been around for quite some time and there is significant advice on the basis for it. The amendments would remove the ability to appoint part-time federal magistrates entirely. The provisions have been drafted to minimise any risk of it being held to be unconstitutional. In particular, the government has been mindful of the decision of the High Court of Australia in Wilson and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

Part-time magistrates could be very useful; they would give additional flexibility in the use of judicial resources. An example not mentioned by the member for Barton is that there may be a regional location which did not have the workload to warrant a full-time federal magistrate but it may be useful to be able to appoint someone on a part-time basis. The bill has been drafted to minimise the possibility of conflicts of interest arising with federal magistrates being involved in other activities. For example, federal magistrates are expressly prevented from practising as lawyers. There would be a number of other occupations which it would not be appropriate for a part-time federal magistrate to occupy. It does give flexibility in respect of parents with child-caring responsibilities, as the member for Barton mentions. In here, the government particularly has in mind the opportunity to appoint well-qualified women who have child-care responsibilities.

The question of the reduction in the salaries is one that would have to be dealt with administratively. It is not a matter for legislation, because it is already provided for in the Constitution. The government is well aware of that and would take appropriate steps.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Williams)—by leave—read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 24 June (on motion by Mr Williams):
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 1, 8 and 10:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 11, item 25, page 40 (line 24)—41 (line 18), omit proposed section 33C.
(8) Schedule 11 item 63, page 48 (line 9) to 49 (line 20), omit the item.
(10) Schedule 12, item 6, page 59 (line 26) to 60 (line 21), omit proposed section 32AC.

These amendments relate to the earlier debate with respect to the Federal Magistrates Bill 1999 and specifically with respect to the determination of the jurisdiction of the Magistrates Court. Amendment 1 will delete clause 25 of schedule 11 of the Federal Magistrates (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 , which relates to proposed section 33C. Amendment 8 will delete item 63 of schedule 11 of the consequential amendments bill, which relates to proposed section 69MA. Amendment 10 will delete item 6 of schedule 12 of the consequential amendments bill, which relates to proposed section 32AC.

Clause 25 of schedule 11 and clause 6 of schedule 12, together with section 41 of the Federal Magistrates Bill, provide that certain types of proceedings specified by regulation can be mandatorily transferred from any of the federal courts. Section 63 of schedule 11 allows the minister to proclaim at any time during the next four years that the federal magistrates shall have jurisdiction to make final orders regarding the residence of children, whether or not the parties consent. This will enable a minister rather than the parliament to effectively define the jurisdiction of these federal courts.

It is the Australian Labor Party's view that the jurisdiction of our courts should always be determined by statute and should not merely be at the whim of the government of the day or an individual minister or the Attorney-General. In so doing, we cast no aspersions or criticism on the current incumbent of that office; merely we think that the office itself is not appropriate to solely determine those issues. We note again that the Law Council of Australia supports this view. Accordingly, we oppose these provisions of the bills. Again, if and when the government wishes to extend or limit the jurisdiction of any court, the Australian Labor Party will consider the issue on its merits. However, we will not give the government the power to determine these issues in advance. Although I note again that the regulations and the proclamation would be subject to limited parliamentary control by way of a disallowance motion, it is not the same thing, in our submission, as the parliament determining the jurisdiction through appropriate provisions in legislation.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes each of these amendments. The issues raised are really issues that have already been debated in relation to the Federal Magistrates Bill. Amendment No. 1 would delete proposed section 33C from item 25. This section would allow regulations to be made which mandate the transfer of proceedings from the Family Court to the Federal Magistrates Service. Once again, this clause is intended to give flexibility in managing the workload of the courts to ensure that the workload is appropriately balanced between the courts. Again, I point out that regulations made under this clause are disallowable and would not come into effect until the period for disallowance by parliament had expired.

speech.para: Amendment No. 8 would delete item 63, which inserts section 69MA. This is the section which would give the Federal Magistrates Service jurisdiction in family law residence matters where the parties seek orders by consent or where the parties consent to the Federal Magistrates Service hearing in determining the proceedings. This section also allows a disallowable proclamation to be made within four years of the commencement of operation of the Federal Magistrates Service, after which the service could have unlimited residence jurisdiction. The Senate committee report indicates, as the member for Barton has just indicated on behalf of the Labor Party, that opposition is on the grounds that the jurisdiction of courts should be determined by statute, not by the government of the day.

The amendment would remove entirely the family law residence jurisdiction of the Federal Magistrates Service. It would even remove the court's ability to deal with family law residence matters where the parties seek orders by consent or where the parties consent to the Federal Magistrates Service hearing and determining the proceeding. It should be pointed out that even state magistrates can deal with residence matters in these circumstances. There is no reason why the Federal Magistrates Service should not be able to do so as well.

The jurisdiction would allow families to have access to a final decision about residence of their children more quickly and cheaply than in the Family Court, which would also result in the need for fewer interim applications. This proposed section also allows a proclamation to be made within four years, resulting in the court having unlimited residence jurisdiction. This provision was included so that it was transparent where family law jurisdiction of the Federal Magistrates Service was headed. The proclamation has been deliberately made disallowable by parliament so that it is subject to parliamentary control. Again, it is intended to give flexibility in managing the workload of the courts in the initial years, and the power would sunset after a period of four years.

Amendment No. 10 would delete proposed section 32AC from item 6. This proposed section would allow regulations to be made which mandate the transfer of proceedings from the Federal Court to the Federal Magistrates Service. Once again, the purpose is to give flexibility in managing the workload of the courts to ensure the workload is appropriately balanced between the courts. Again, regulations made under this clause are disallowable and would not come into effect until the period for disallowance by parliament had expired.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 2 to 7 inclusive:

speech.para: (2) Schedule 11, item 42, page 44 (lines 4-8), omit paragraph 45A(1)(a), substitute:
"(a) proceedings are instituted in the Federal Magistrates Court in relation to property of a total value exceeding, at the time the proceedings are commenced
(ii) if another amount is specified in the regulations—that other amount; and".
(3) Schedule 11, item 42, page 44 (after line 16) after subsection (1) insert:
(1A) If,
(a) after proceedings have been instituted in the Federal Magistrates Court in relation to property, the total value of the property exceeds
(ii) if another amount is specified in the regulations—that other amount; and

(b) the respondent in answer to the application by which the proceedings are instituted, is seeking an order different from that sought in the application; the Federal Magistrates Court must, before proceedings further with proceedings, inform the parties that, unless each of them consents to the Federal Magistrates Court continuing to hear and determine the proceedings, the Federal Magistrates Court is required to transfer the proceedings to the Family Court.
(4) Schedule 11, item 42, page 44 (line 18), after "hearing" insert "; or continuing to hear".
(5) Schedule 11, item 42, page 44 (line 20), after "hearing" insert "; or continuing to hear".
(6) Schedule 11, item 42, page 44 (line 24), after "subsection (1)" insert "or (1A)".
(7) Schedule 11, item 42, page 44 (line 28), after "subsection (1)" insert "or (1A)".

These amendments would require the Federal Magistrates Court to transfer proceedings to the Family Court if it were determined, either at the commencement of or at any time during the proceedings, that the total value of the property in dispute exceeded $300,000 or such other amount as is set by regulation. The amendments provide an exception to this rule where both parties consent to the matter remaining before the Federal Magistrates Service.

As the Federal Magistrates (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 is currently drafted, the determination as to whether proceedings should be transferred is made only at the commencement of the proceedings. Frequently, the value of property will not be known or may not be disclosed until midway through the case. This is particularly the case in the family law area in respect of a party who is a proprietor of a business where the value of that business is not fully evident to the other party until midway through the proceedings. Accordingly, neither the Federal Magistrates Court nor the parties will be able to make any informed decision at the commencement of proceedings as to whether the matter should remain with the Federal Magistrates Court. These amendments will allow the court and the parties to make that decision at the time it becomes known that the value of the property exceeds $300,000.

Amendment No. 2 amends the proposed section 45A to make it clear that an initial determination of the value of the property should be made at the time proceedings are commenced. Amendment No. 3 provides the mechanism for the matter to be reconsidered if at any time during the proceedings the value of the property exceeds $300,000. Amendments Nos 4 to 7 are consequential to the above changes. We note that, in all probability, it will not be a situation where a hearing date will have to be adjourned as a result of a party ascertaining or believing that the other party's assets—or the combined assets of the marriage—exceed $300,000.

If the case is properly prepared before hearing, one or other of the parties will ascertain that information—even if it is not disclosed—so that an appropriate application can be made to the federal magistrate at that point in time for the matter to be transferred into the Federal Court so that the actual hearing of the case can be conducted in the Federal Court. If that is not provided for, the purpose and intention of the legislation can be overridden by inadequate information existing at the commencement of the proceedings and locking the parties into proceedings before the magistrate. It may well result in any award, order or verdict of the Magistrates Court being challengeable as a result of such a verdict exceeding the permissible jurisdiction al limit of the Federal Magistrates Court. The Labor Party's amendments are designed to prevent that occurrence.

talk.start.para: —As the member for Barton points out, amendments Nos 2 to 7 would effectively allow the transfer of family law property matters during the conduct of the proceeding if it became apparent during the proceeding that the value of the property in dispute was worth more than $300,000. From what he has said and from the Senate committee's report, it appears that these amendments have been included to address a concern from the Labor Party that it may not be clear at the start of the proceedings how much the property is worth.

speech.para: The Federal Magistrates Service would be obliged to transfer family law property proceedings to the Family Court where, when the proceeding was filed, the property in dispute was worth more than $300,000. The government opposes the amendments that would mandate the transfer of family law property matters during the conduct of the proceedings if it became apparent that the property in dispute was valued at more than the sum of $300,000. The government considers the most appropriate time to look at the value of the property to be when the proceeding is filed, otherwise parties could make transfer applications halfway through the proceeding. This could be used as a delaying tactic and could be disruptive.

Under the arrangements currently in the Federal Magistrates (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 , if there were a possibility that the value of the property was more than $300,000 at the start of the proceedings, the Federal Magistrates Service could simply transfer the proceedings to the Family Court. This would avoid too much time being spent hearing argument about the value of the property. That is not to say that it might not be an issue addressed later on. If the property did increase significantly in value during the proceedings, the Federal Magistrates Service could use its general transfer power to transfer the proceeding to the Family Court if it considered it appropriate, so the matter is not without remedy.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment No. 9:

speech.para: (9) Schedule 12, item 4, page 57 (line 30) to 58 (line 2), omit the item.

This amendment relates to amendment No. 12 to the Federal Magistrates Bill 1999 , which we previously moved. Amendment No. 9 will delete clause 76 of the bill. Proposed section 76(1) in the bill will permit the Federal Magistrates Court to give its reasons, either orally or in writing. These issues were debated earlier. I note that the Attorney-General said in respect of that that he would anticipate that federal magistrates would be anxious to ensure that their decisions were not appealed and that, in that context, they would give adequate reasons. If that is the case, we say that it is appropriate that the legislation actually requires them to give adequate reasons, and it could do that by removing the reference in proposed section 76(5) to the exclusion of the operation of section 25D of the Acts Interpretation Act.

As I have previously noted, that provides that, where there is a reference to reasons, grounds or any similar expression used in an act of parliament, the reasons shall set out the findings on material questions of fact and refer to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based. Indeed, my recollection of significant cases in the area of natural justice—in particular, in respect of domestic tribunals—is to the effect that those tribunals are required to give reasons for their determinations and that those reasons must refer to material questions of fact and to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based. I think they are determined by the courts to be the fundamental principles of natural justice.

It is probably the case that these exclusions would be regarded uncomfortably by the High Court. Indeed, the High Court would probably require there to be an express exclusion of the principles of natural justice if it were to be argued that these provisions of the act enabled the magistrates to give decisions without referring to material questions of fact and to the evidence or other material upon which those findings were based.

Given that strong and consistent line of authority, we say it is inappropriate, wrong and contrary to those fundamental principles of natural justice to exclude that requirement and suggest, as the legislation suggests, that federal magistrates will be able to give reasons for a decision in a form which is other than adequate and, in particular, not adequately advise the parties of why they arrived at their conclusion. As I previously said, in particular we need to ensure that the parties appreciate the reasons for a decision. This is vitally important in the family law area, where there can be so much distrust of the court which deliberates in respect of, in particular, child residence and access issues.

If a party were not satisfied that the magistrate had adequately comprehended their argument, it would be grounds for discontent, which we see frequently. Indeed, we have seen the manifestation of that in the family law area in the violence perpetrated not only on the court but also on the other party. It is an area where, as much as possible, all parties should be advised of the reasoning in making these very significant decisions, which are extremely close and personal and go to the root of all relationships—namely, decisions about access and other residence of children.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes opposition amendment No. 9. Most of what the member for Barton said in his eloquent appeal actually related to amendment No. 12 of the Federal Magistrates Bill 1999 , which the House has previously rejected. My understanding of amendment No. 9 is that it is a narrow one, seeking to delete item 4 from schedule 12 of the Federal Court of Australia Act. The amendment would therefore delete section 28(6) which it is proposed be added to that act. Under this subsection, the full court of the Federal Court could give reasons in short form in accordance with the rules of court when dismissing an appeal where that appeal does not raise any general question of principle.

speech.para: From what the member for Barton has said and from the Senate committee report, it appears that the opposition opposes this clause, but it considers that the parties should know why decisions are being made for or against them. For my part, I do not accept that what the courts have said about reasons required of domestic tribunals in the exercise of judgment about what the rules of natural justice or procedural fairness require is directly relevant here. In my view, it would be open to the legislature to determine what is appropriate in the context. In any event, rules of procedural fairness are not immutable; they vary in accordance with the circumstances.

The clause proposed to be added by the Federal Magistrates (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 would allow the Federal Court to give short form reasons in accordance with the rules of court when dismissing an appeal where that appeal does not raise any general question of principle. Once again, even if the court gives reasons in short form, parties will still know what those reasons are. It is not intended to negate any common law obligation to give proper reasons for a decision. It will apply only where the Federal Court is dismissing an appeal and that appeal does not raise any general question of principle, and it will not apply in all appeals.

Having regard to the standard of the membership of the Federal Court, one can imagine that the reasons in most cases will be of a very high standard indeed, even if they are in short form and even if they are delivered orally. The Federal Court suggested this amendment itself to allow it to deal with appeals more efficiently. I recommend the amendment proposed in the bill rather than the amendment proposed by the opposition.
Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes schedule 25. Amendment No. 11 is a very significant amendment from the position of the Australian Labor Party. It proposes the deletion of schedule 25 of the bill. Schedule 25 deals with amendments of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and provides for the ability of these federal magistrates to determine certain issues under that act. In particular, it would enable the federal magistrates to exercise injunctive powers to stop or prevent industrial action under section 127 of the Workplace Relations Act. They are included in items 1 to 6 of schedule 25 of the consequential amendments bill. It would also enable federal magistrates to deal with the freedom of association provisions contained in part XA of the Workplace Relations Act. They are contained in items 7 through 11 of schedule 25 of the consequential amendment bill.

speech.para: As I indicated in my speech in the second reading debate, these are notoriously complex areas of law and are inappropriate for determination at a magistrates level. For instance, the determination of section 127 orders applies in respect of some of the most dramatic industrial cases we have seen in recent years such as Rio Tinto and Arco. A whole range of very dramatic industrial disputes have been the subject of section 127 orders. The nature of these applications is that they require urgent relief and quite frequently the applications are made overnight. They would require the federal magistrates to down tools on all other matters and give those issues priority.

Notoriously, these issues involve very complex considerations. Increasingly, the Federal Court is having regard to international treaty obligations on the part of Australia in construing legislation and specifically international treaty obligations regarding freedom of association and collective bargaining in construing the application of these provisions, as indeed it is doing in the area of freedom of association provisions. Again, last year we saw a very dramatic case involving freedom of association provisions in the waterfront dispute. We feel that this is more a case of the government trying to bypass the messenger of the Federal Court of Australia in its determination that the government had acted inappropriately in its relationship with the employers in the waterfront dispute rather than a genuine desire to think through a rational allocation of appropriate jurisdiction to the Federal Magistrates Court.

If you look at the nature of those very dramatic and very urgent cases as against what would be appropriate to determine at magistrates level, the suspicion is heightened in respect of the government's motives. For instance, it would be more appropriate, and indeed probably very appropriate, for these federal magistrates to be given jurisdiction to determine unfair dismissal cases, but that has not occurred. Indeed, there is precedence of state industrial magistrates dealing with cases under section 178 of the Workplace Relations Act in the enforcement of awards. But, again, the federal magistrates are not being given those jurisdictions. Those claims relate to underpayment of wages and the like.

The government is not giving the federal magistrates those relatively simple, straightforward cases. It is giving it power in these very dramatic, very politically charged issues where the Federal Court, I think it is fair to say, has been inclined to decide against the aggressor rather than the party defending their rights. In so arriving at conclusions to that effect, as discontented as the government may well be with the Federal Court applying international principles, it is no reason for the rational allocation of jurisdiction to the Federal Magistrates Court. Quite frankly, this is an issue where the Australian Labor Party will be opposed to the bitter end because we see political undertones rather than rational planning in the government's action.

talk.start.para: —I will not hold up the operation of the House for long, but I would like to support the remarks of the member for Barton, the shadow Attorney-General, regarding this amendment which seeks to delete schedule 25 of the bill and which, as the member for Barton said, relates to the issue of jurisdiction in relation to the Workplace Relations Act. The member for Barton raised a number of very important issues as to the operation of, in an industrial setting, the Federal Magistrates Court versus the Federal Court. He raised some important examples of concerns that are legitimately held about how that would in fact come into play.

speech.para: When we look at the role of the Federal Court most recently in a significant sense on the waterfront dispute, the Federal Court did play a very important role in seeing a just settlement reached in some of the matters that were raised and certainly in terms of ensuring that access was provided for natural justice to a range of the employees and parties involved. When we look at why this particular matter has been removed from the Federal Court to the Federal Magistrates Court, we have to ask ourselves: why has the government sought to do this?
Mr Albanese interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know that the member for Grayndler has had a great deal of experience over the years when it comes to the question of the magistrate's court, amongst other levels. But, in this particular case, we have to look at some very serious issues. When we look at issues in relation to the Federal Magistrates Court and the Federal Court and in particular, as the member for Barton said, issues in relation to unfair dismissal, there is no doubt that unfair dismissal issues are not as complex as some of the other matters which we believe to be in the bill and which we are seeking to amend with respect to the Federal Court. There are issues there that are much more complex.

speech.para: As a former union official, I often dealt with matters such as unfair dismissal. Quite frankly, the lower the level of court, the lower the level of arbitration, the better it is to sort out the problems, leading to a proper and just resolution. When we look at this particular schedule we see that the government is proposing to give the Federal Magistrates Court injunctive powers to stop or prevent industrial action under section 127 and the power to cancel the registration of an organisation for breach of freedom of association provisions. They are serious matters—matters which should not be considered lightly.

When we look at this proposal, we say that it will be okay for these things to be handled at a magistracy court level; but other matters, such as unfair dismissal, as I mentioned, are much less appropriate in the circumstances. This does not make sense. This raises the question of what the government's agenda appears to be in the industrial relations field. The fact is that the government missed out with respect to the maritime dispute in that the Federal Court did not do their bidding. As the Federal Court has considered those issues on their merit and tried to inject some natural justice into the proceedings, the government has sought to say, `Okay, you are not going to handle a lot of that stuff anymore. We are going to take it away. We are going to remove it from you and give it to another level.' That raises questions of who are the magistrates who will be considering such issues? Who are the magistrates who will be involved? What will be their qualifications to handle these sorts of matters which are, as has been said by the member for Barton, particularly complex? There are some real issues there.

The government ought to look at those issues and see what they are doing. They ought to consider whether those issues are being moved to another level as a matter of political expediency. They ought to consider whether, in relation to the resolution of a dispute from 12 months ago, they are, in effect, seeking to resolve such issues in the future on the basis of this alteration of jurisdiction. They should get a system in place which makes sense. When they address issues of the operation of the Federal Magistrates Court they should ensure that the Federal Magistrates Court has proper and appropriate areas to consider; they should not try to use it to remove matters from the Federal Court simply because it suits them politically.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes the opposition amendment. The opposition opposes the entire schedule 25 dealing with Workplace Relations Act 1996 matters. The schedule would give the Federal Magistrates Service jurisdiction under section 127 and part XA of the Workplace Relations Act to make various other amendments consequential upon the conferring of that jurisdiction. Section 127 allows orders to be made by the court after orders have been made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to stop or prevent industrial action, and part XA contains the freedom of association provisions.

speech.para: In the minority report from the Senate committee, the opposition indicates that it opposes the jurisdiction being vested in the service on the basis that such matters involve complex areas of law, and the opposition alleges that there is a government plan to prevent the Federal Court from hearing such matters. There is no plan that I am aware of in that respect.

The one thing that we have not had acknowledged it seems to me in either the Senate committee report or the reasons given by the members for Barton and Bruce in relation to the amendment is a recognition and acknowledgment that the Federal Court would have concurrent jurisdiction. So it would be up to the litigants to determine in which court to commence proceedings, and not every case that is going to arise under section 127 or part XA is going to be complex. The reason for setting up the Federal Magistrates Service is for it to deal with simple and less complex cases. The only case we hear mentioned is the waterfront case from last year. I cannot imagine that the applicants to the Federal Court in that case would have ever contemplated commencing their proceedings in a magistrate's court.

No jurisdiction is being removed from the Federal Court. The parties would simply be able to choose whether to proceed in the Federal Court or the Federal Magistrates Court. A proceeding would be able to be transferred between the Federal Magistrates Service and the Federal Court on the application of a party or on the initiative of the court. This would ensure that proceedings are dealt with in the most appropriate forum, and in many cases the Federal Magistrates Court would be the most appropriate forum.

The object in giving jurisdiction to the Federal Magistrates Service is to provide appropriate access to quick, low cost relief, particularly for ordinary workers in relation to breaches of key aspects of workplace relations law—something that one would have contemplated the Labor Party might have supported. The Federal Magistrates Service is being set up specifically to deal with more routine matters, freeing up the superior courts to deal with complex cases. I have no doubt that more complex cases would continue to be dealt with by the Federal Court.

The member for Barton mentioned that unfair dismissals jurisdiction is not conferred on the Federal Magistrates Service under the legislation. My recollection is that the unfair dismissals jurisdiction is now exercised by the commissioner, not by courts. On that basis, there is no reason for amending the arrangements. I indicated that the government opposes the Labor Party amendment. I would invite the Labor Party, in further debate on this particular aspect of the bill, to try to eliminate some of the paranoia that seems to surround its consideration of the issue.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That Senate amendment No. 1 be disagreed to.

The modernisation of the principal legislation regulating the Australian Public Service, the Public Service Act 1922, is a vital element of the government's Public Service reform agenda. The current act is prescriptive and out of date. It has acted like a straitjacket on the Australian Public Service, stifling the creativity and innovation of those who work within the service. The Public Service Bill 1999 aims to modernise the Australian Public Service—APS—legislative framework and transform the APS management culture.

The changes necessary to achieve this transformation are effected through this bill. The changes provide a careful balance between devolved responsibility and improved accountability. They provide the means of freeing APS agencies from central controls and they free up APS agencies to adopt employment arrangements that meet their particular needs.

In essence, the bill aims to put in place a framework for a high performance Public Service while recognising the distinctive character of public administration in a way that is absent from the current legislation. The bill does not prescribe process but instead ensures that agency heads are held accountable for their actions. It removes prescription and central control and will enable the Public Service to meet market competition, to respond to pressures for change more effectively, and to promote a stronger performance culture. It will bring Public Service employment arrangements into line with community standards and, at the same time, it will promote accountability by making managers responsible for the way they manage employment matters within their own agencies.

I am before the House again with this legislation, because the Senate accepted an opposition amendment to clause 22 that goes to the employment in the APS of non-ongoing employees. The amendment allows the employment of such employees only on the basis of regulations over which the Senate has the power of disallowance. The government is unable to accept the amendment, because it effectively outlaws employment in the APS for a specified term or for a specified task unless regulations are made.

The government has made changes to the bill in the context of seeking reasonable compromise and bipartisan support. There has been constructive consideration and negotiation on these issues and the government has appreciated the positive approach taken by the opposition. In that context, further discussions have occurred over the amendment passed by the Senate, and I am pleased to advise the House that an acceptable compromise has been reached which will allow the bill to pass both houses of parliament without the amendment to clause 22 passed by the Senate.

The compromise involves a commitment by the government to clarify in regulations the grounds on which the engagement of persons for specified terms may be extended by an agency head. The government has negotiated in good faith with the opposition over the last five months in recognition of their position as an alternative government and has sought reasonable compromise and bipartisan support. Agreement has now been reached on a bill which will significantly advance our shared aims for a modern public sector framework. The government therefore rejects the Senate amendment to clause 22 and will be rejecting an identical amendment, Senate amendment No. 2, made to the Parliamentary Service Bill 1999 . The government, however, accepts the other amendments: Senate amendment No. 2 to the Public Service Bill 1999 , amendments Nos 1, 3 and 4 to the Parliamentary Service Bill 1999, and all Senate amendments to the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1999.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That Senate amendments Nos 1 to 16 and Nos 18 to 27 be agreed to.

I have moved that these amendments be agreed to, although the government does not necessarily agree with some of the amendments to the recognisable interests of the Senate. The government will accept the amendments put forward by the opposition as well as those put forward by the government in the Senate.

The government does not agree to Senate amendment No. 17, because the grandfather clause is not merited in this instance. Firstly, this is a clear case of double dipping, which should not be supported. Secondly, as pointed out to all the Senate parties, the amendment as put by the Democrats is flawed and subsequently cannot be supported. For these reasons, the government is not supportive of this particular Senate amendment.

talk.start.para: —I rise to first of all express some pleasure at the fact that the Labor Party in the Senate has been able to amend the Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999 to improve the legislation. Firstly, we thwarted the government's attempts to knock off the employment entry payment. We similarly stopped them from removing the education entry payment from allowance recipients. We also stopped them from imposing a double liquid assets waiting period on students who pay for their own study while supporting themselves. Where we continue to disagree with the government is in their treatment of CDEP and the changes that they propose. We in fact accept the government's advice that the amendment, which was drafted by the Democrats, does not achieve its objective.

speech.para: The Democrats will, we understand, be redrafting their amendment, and we will be supporting that in the Senate and therefore it will come back to the House for further substantive debate. The point also needs to be made that that is not our preferred position. Our preferred position is not to have a grandfathering clause. Our preferred position is simply to knock off this draconian measure in total.

This measure is not about double dipping. This measure is about stopping the current circumstances whereby indigenous people are treated the same as other Australians are. We need to examine what exactly this change does. This change is aimed at ripping off $80 a week from indigenous people who participate in CDEP in remote areas. If you think about the most disadvantaged people in our society, it is very hard to think of a more disadvantaged category than single parents who are indigenous and live in remote areas. This is Pythonesque in its draconian nature and is reinforcement of this government's being full of people who have graduated from the Margaret Thatcher school of kicking beggars. That is what they are about. The poorer and more disadvantaged you are, the more pleasure this mob get from taking away your income.

What we are talking about here is that sole parents who currently participate in CDEP are currently able to keep $100 a fortnight—just as other single parents who work are able to earn up to $102 a fortnight without losing some of their benefits. What happens currently is that, of the $330 that is paid as a contribution for the CDEP, $100 is kept by the sole parent and $230 of that money is paid into the community. That is the beauty of CDEP. The government gives us all this rhetoric, and we hear the Minister for Employment, Training and Youth Affairs asked the same question day after day about Work for the Dole. He comes up here and says, `We support Work for the Dole. We think it is a terrific scheme.' Well, the first, and model, Work for the Dole program was of course the CDEP. It is a good program, because the money is paid into the community, to the benefit of the community, for schemes which increase the infrastructure of that community.

Here we have a government which is saying, `We will take money off indigenous sole parents who are participating in that scheme.' It is mean spirited, it is heartless and we will not have a bar of it. That is why we will support the Democrats' amendment, weak as it is with the grandfathering clause, but it is better than this government's approach. We will continue to raise these issues. This could well have been part of the secret document that Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services, will not release. We do not know what is in that document—

talk.start.para: —It is still in the bottom drawer.

—the great visionary document that is in the bottom drawer. What we do know is that these are the sorts of cuts that this government envisages in the name of reform. It is not reform; it is just about cutting and taking away people's rights and benefits. That is why we put on the record our opposition again today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think it is worth while getting up to put a few things on the record. I endorse all the comments made by the honourable member for Grayndler, who has had carriage of this matter in this House. The points he makes are valid points. But this minister, the Minister for Community Services, should be ashamed of himself. The CDEP has a bit of history, and he more than anyone should know it because his father was part of the cabinet that sponsored the CDEP. Malcolm Fraser was the Prime Minister who brought CDEP in. It has got a 22-year history. It has been an important and integral part of indigenous communities in helping rebuild those communities. It was the initial Work for the Dole.

speech.para: The trouble is that this government, under this Prime Minister, are going back to the old dark days. There should be incentives for CDEP participants. They are disadvantaged as it is. They are going out there and working. For this minister to be getting up as enthusiastically as he is and supporting what this Prime Minister is doing, shame on you, because the history is that in remote and regional communities the employment is not there. Moving those people into cities where employment occurs will create further disadvantage and dislocation of those communities. That is why we should not apologise if CDEP recipients receive some further benefits. We should be arguing that they are out there working for the dole. Single mothers should not be disadvantaged by this. So I am a bit disappointed that again we will be supporting the second-best option because the Democrats have come up with a halfway house.

In this area I think the government have a lot to answer for. We should remember that in the first budget they quarantined an expansion of 2,500 places. It was just madness. In the subsequent budget in 1997 they released another 600 places. This government need to think again in relation to CDEP. There should be those incentives for people who are not going to find employment. It is not the same situation as in the cities where, if you engage in Work for the Dole programs and training, you are going to find employment. You are not going to. That is why the Labor Party has, in a whole range of other areas as well, taken the position on CDEP.

A lot of the amendments that the government are now accepting are amendments that we have insisted on and the Democrats came on board. Why? Because we think that is the way forward. The fact is that we did thwart the government's attempts to knock off the employment entry payment, and we stopped them from removing education entry payment from allowance recipients. That is all important stuff. This minister needs to understand that, from the Labor Party's point of view, we are getting sick and tired of the class based attitude of this government—and that is what it is. They are taking from the poor to give to the rich.

The Victorians have just despatched Jeff Kennett. He has been Jeffed today. Today is his last day as Premier, and Steven Bracks takes over as Premier tomorrow. As far as this government's attitude of dividing the community and, in effect, continuing to take away from the disadvantaged and the poor to give to their mates is concerned, the electors are waiting for you. In a couple of years time you will see.

I commend my colleague and friend the honourable member for Grayndler because he has championed this debate on behalf of the opposition. The fact that a number of these amendments have been accepted by the government in the Senate is a vindication of the championing of these positions by both him and the honourable member for Lilley. It is the Labor Party that has run the line on these amendments and the Democrats, frankly, have followed suit. It is a pity that in relation to amendment No. 17—we are going to reject amendment No. 17—we are again coming up with this halfway house. I intervene in the debate to say that these are substantial amendments from our point of view. We think that they improve the bill, and that is why we have accepted those other amendments. I think this minister needs to be very wary of this Prime Minister. He should take the lead from the Fraser government's approach—an approach that his predecessor, his father, was involved in. A bit of compassion goes a long way. You do not have to go through Thatcher. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I thank the previous speaker, the member for Banks, for his partial interpretation of history. Indeed, I do remember the 1967 referendum. My father was very active in that particular cause as well, as was mentioned before, CDEP having been brought in by the Fraser government.
—You don't wind it back.

—We are not winding it back, however we do not believe that it is appropriate to have double dipping. In this case, as was pointed out by some members of the opposition—I think they feel a little boxed in because of the Democrats's move—the grandfather clause is inconsistent with the fiscal objectives of the CDEP package contained in the bill which implemented important features of the Spicer report and which were supported by ATSIC. By negating the entire item 53 in the bill in relation to lone parents, it has the effect of disentitling the group from eligibility for the CDEP participation supplement. In conclusion, as I have said before in this place, the measure is a strong support of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

—It is true. The measure, as supported by ATSIC, ends the situation where a small group of people are able to legally claim two income support payments. —I am happy to speak again. The member for Richmond makes a couple of interesting claims.
—The minister.

—The Minister for Community Services—the member for Richmond for the moment—firstly says that a grandfather clause is inappropriate and does not fit in with the current methods of the way that the CDEP operates. We would agree in part because that is why we think that this measure, this draconian change by the government, should not be supported at all. But a grandfather clause is better than nothing at all. What a grandfather clause will do is ensure that those single parents who are currently participants in CDEP who earn $330 for their participation in that program, who contribute $230 to their community by that participation, who get a whole $100 a fortnight by their participation in that scheme, will not have their social security cut. The fact is that, unless there is grandfathering, people who currently earn $100 a fortnight will have that cut back to $20 a fortnight. In the name of equity and fairness, I do not think so, Minister.

speech.para: This is the government that promised that no Australian would be worse off. Remember that promise prior to the 1996 election? Yet it wants to take $80 from indigenous sole parents in remote areas. That is what this is about—$80. That might not be much to the spivs with their family trusts who occupy the front bench, but it is a lot to indigenous sole parents. That is what this mob wants to do.

The second point that those opposite raise concerns ATSIC and its alleged support for this government measure. Minister, when it comes back to the House, we will be tabling the advice that we have from ATSIC. ATSIC, in fact, has written to senators saying that, having examined it, it no longer supports this government measure. Having examined the fact that it will take $80 per fortnight out of the pockets of indigenous sole parents, ATSIC does not want a bar of it, Minister. This is in spite of the fact of your having stood over it, just as you have done with other community and representative organisations—with the women's groups; with the Pensioners and Superannuants Federation; with AYPAC, the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition; just as you have done with every one of those organisations. subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Mr Reith:

upon which Ms Macklin moved by way of amendment:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading the House expresses its concern about the nature of the bill and its contribution to the stripping back of Government support for Australian women and the community organisations that represent them, in particular:

(1) the weakening of industrial relations legislation and organisations that aim to improve women's employment prospects and workplace treatment, particularly through the Workplace Relations Act and reductions in the power of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission;

(2) the weakening of organisations that exist to provide women with suitable avenues of redress for discrimination, including the Affirmative Action Agency and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission;
(3) failure to respond to major reports, particularly the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Report, Pregnant and Productive ;

(4) failure to send appropriate representation to international forums discussing women's policy, particularly to the recent International Labour Organisation's conference on maternity leave provisions;
(5) the weakening of the role of government organisations that aim to improve the sensitivity of government policies to women, particularly the Office of the Status of Women;
(6) the de-funding of community groups which represent women, including the Girl Guides, the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Older Women's Network and the Catholic Women's League;
(7) failure to consult with a wide range of women's organisations, particularly through the reduction in the numbers now attending the national round table consultations;
(8) cuts to child care, education and health-services which women depend upon to be able to work, to raise a family and to improve their living standards;
